step1.sentence: I have never cooked Thai food before, but I figured I would give it a shot.

step2.story: The painting class had seemed intimidating for weeks. One Tuesday she ran out of excuses and signed up, telling herself she was simply going to give it a shot. By the end of the second session, she had stopped thinking about being good at it and started just enjoying it.

step3.story: The company had always sourced its software from established vendors. When a developer on the team proposed building a key internal tool from scratch instead, the idea was received with skepticism. The project would take time, carry risk, and require learning. The manager said she would give it a shot — a narrow pilot with a clear end date and measurable criteria. The pilot ran six weeks over schedule, cost more than estimated, and produced a tool that was faster and more adaptable than anything they could have licensed. The risk had been real. So had the payoff.

meaning.realUsageKo: 결과를 모르더라도 한번 시도해 볼 때 씁니다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 총을 한 번 쏘아보는 이미지에서 나온 구어 표현입니다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 낮은 기대와 열린 마음을 함께 담은, 가볍고 실용적인 시도를 표현합니다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: Why not give it a shot — you have nothing to lose.
